references.B02MOS01USGP: Mostrom, Alison M., Robert L. Curry and Bernard Lohr. 2002. Carolina Chickadee (Poecile carolinensis), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/636
references.B88ROO01NAUS: Root, T. 1988. Atlas of wintering North American birds:An analysis of Christmas Bird Count data. University of Chicago Press. 336 pp.
references.A93GIL01NAUS: Gill, F. B., A. M. Mostrom, and A. L. Mack. 1993. Speciation in North American chickadees:I. Patterns of mtDNA genetic divergence. Evolution 47:195-212.
references.B92SIM01NCGP: Simpson M.B Jr. 1992. Birds of the Blue Ridge Mountains. Chapel Hill and London: University of North Carolina Press.
references.A81KEN01NCGP: Kendeigh, S.C. and B.  Fawver. 1981. Breeding bird populations in the Great Smoky Mountains, Tennessee ad North Carolina. Wilson Bulletin: 93:218-42.
references.B96KAU01NCGP: Kaufman K. 1996. Lives of North American Birds. Boston, New York: Houghton Mifflin Company.
references.B80TER01NAUS: Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
references.B79HAR01NAUS: Harrison, H.H. 1979. A field guide to western birds' nests. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston. 279 pp.
references.B92HAM01NAUS: Hamel, P. B. 1992. The land manager's guide to the birds of the south. The Nature Conservancy, Chapel Hill, North Carolina. 367 pp + several appendices.
references.B94FUS01NCGP: Fussell, J.O. III. 1994. A birder's guide to coastal North Carolina. Chapel Hill and London: The University of North Carolina Press.
references.B80POT01NAUS: Potter, E. F., J. F. Parnell, and R. P. Teulings. 1980. Birds of the Carolinas. Univ. North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill. 408 pp.
references.A92SHE02NAUS: Sheldon, F. H., et al. 1992. DNA-DNA hybridization evidence of phylogenetic relationships among major lineages of PARUS. Auk 109:173-185.
references.B83AOU01USGP: American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
references.B88MIT01NAUS: Mitchell, W.A. 1988. Songbird nest boxes. Section 5.1.8, U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Wildlife Resources Management Manual. Tech. Rep. EL-88-19. Waterways Experiment Station, Vicksburg, Mississippi. 48 pp.
references.B75HAR01HQUS: Harrison, H.H. 1975. A field guide to bird's nests in the U.S. east of the Mississippi River. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. 257 p.
references.B46BEN01NAUS: Bent, A.C. 1946. Life histories of North American jays, crows, and titmice. U.S. Natl. Mus. Bull. 191. Washington, D.C.
references.A89ROB03NAUS: Robbins, M. 1989. What's your name, my little chickadee? Birding 21:205-207.
references.A52TAN01USGP: Tanner, J. T. 1952. Black-capped and Carolina Chickadees in the southern Appalachian Mountains. Auk 69:407-423.
references.A71JOH02USGP: Johnston, D. W. 1971. Ecological aspects of hybridizing chickadees (Parus) in Virginia. Am. Midl. Nat. 85:124-134.
references.B95HAR01USGP: Harrap, S. and D. Quinn. 1995. Chickadees, tits, nuthatches, and treecreepers. Christopher Helm, London.
references.B78HAR01NAUS: Harrison, C. 1978. A field guide to the nests, eggs and nestlings of North American birds. Collins, Cleveland, Ohio.

habitat_description:
Southeast:
Carolina chickadees are present throughout the southeast (excluding southern Florida) except on some of the barrier islands (Fussell 1994) and in high elevation mountains where Carolina chickadees are found (Potter et al 1980, Simpson 1992). They breed in medium to mature woods, where dead trees or stubs are present for nesting. Hamel (1992) asserts they are most common in mixed pine-hardwoods and pinewoods, and less common in pure hardwood forests, while Kaufman (1996) states they are 'mostly in deciduous forests.'  Also occur in woodland edges, suburban areas, and wooded parks (Hamel 1992, Simpson 1992). Nest in cavities, either excavated by the breeding pair or existing cavity such old woodpecker hole (Hamel 1992, Kaufman 1996, Potter et al 1980). Cavities usually dug out in 'softwood of fence post, decaying stump, or dead stub on a living tree,' according to Potter et al (1980).
In se. U.S., inhabits: (1) swamp forests consisting of oak (Quercus sp.), water tupelo (Nyssa aquatica), black gum (N. sylvatica), sweetgum (Liquidamber styraciflua), and cypress (Taxodium sp.); (2) maritime/riparian hardwood forests of (a) live oak (Q. virginiana); (b) elm (Ulmus spp.), ash (Fraxinus spp.), and cottonwood (Populus deltoides or P. heterophylla); (3) mid- to late-successional mesic hardwood forests of (a) American beech (Fagus grandifolia) and southern magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora); (b) tulip (yellow) poplar (Liriodendron tulipifera), basswood (Tilia heterophylla), sugar maple (Acer saccharum), buckeye (Aesculus octandra), and white oak (Q. alba); (c) sugar maple, beech, and yellow birch (Betula lutea); (4) upland hardwood forests of scrub oaks; (5) mid- to late-successional mixed pine (Pinus)-hardwood forests of (a) loblolly pine (P. taeda), shortleaf pine (P. echinata), and oak spp.; (b) sand pine (P. clausa) and scrub oaks; (c) longleaf pine (P. palustris) and scrub oaks; and (d) longleaf pine and mixed hardwoods; (e) white pine (P. strobus), oaks, and hickories (Carya spp.); (6) mid- to late-successional pine forests of (a) loblolly pine and shortleaf pine; (b) scrub pine (P. virginiana) and pitch pine (P. rigida); (c) white pine and eastern hemlock (Tsuga canadensis); and (d) longleaf pine (Hamel 1992). Throughout range, inhabits parks and well-wooded suburban and even urban areas (e.g., Hadidian et al. 1997)(quoted directly from Mostrom et al. 2002).

Great Plains:
Restricted in southwestern part of range to riverine habitats (Harrap and Quinn 1995). In Great Plain states, found in tree-shrub-savanna communities, but not in prairie grasslands and dry-belt pine forests (Bent 1946, Root 1988)(quoted directly from Mostrom et al. 2002).

All Regions:
In mountains, ranges to 1,850 m in absence of Black-capped Chickadees (Bent 1946, Tanner 1952, Kendeigh and Fawver 1981); upper-elevation limit possibly lower (1,000–1,200 m) in presence of Black-capped Chickadees, which reside typically at higher elevations, with or without gap in altitudinal distribution during breeding season (Tanner 1952, Johnston 1971, Pitts 1997). Throughout range, inhabits parks and well-wooded suburban and even urban areas (e.g., Hadidian et al. 1997)(quoted directly from Mostrom et al. 2002).
